content: Hi ! I'm a second year undergraduate from Warwick doing a summer project in Lean. Is it still possible to join the Xena project server ?
It's a top secret server for elite Lean users. @Kevin Buzzard will PM you an invite link if you are qualified.
Just patiently wait.

I am not sure about élite, since I have been admitted a long time ago! In any case, there are certainly élite users in the Discord!

Also, for context, Paul will be working with me on a project around Galois theory.

To clear up any confusion about the joke in @Huỳnh Trần Khanh's message, it is absolutely not exclusively for elite users, but access to it is generally handled on a case-by-case basis. As an undergraduate doing a summer project, you'd definitely be welcome (although it's not my call to make)!
I'm sure @Bhavik Mehta will be happy to extend an invite when he signs on to zulip ;)
Out of curiosity, what maths around Galois theory were you planning to formalize in this project?

We have not really settled on something specific yet: the project is supposed to start at the end of this month. We had been thinking about relating Galois group over different fields, with a view towards Dedekind's Theorem.
Though I have not yet looked at what is already available, so our aims might change!
Sounds great! Looking forward to your mathlib PRs :wink:
Thanks ! I'm looking to working on it :smiley:
Invite sent. What is Dedekind's theorem?

Here is something I would very much like to have in Lean: if L/KL/KL/K is a finite extension of global fields and PPP is a prime of KKK which splits as ∏iQiei\prod_iQ_i^{e_i}∏i​Qiei​​ in LLL then KP⊗KL=⨁iLQiK_P\otimes_KL=\bigoplus_iL_{Q_i}KP​⊗K​L=⨁i​LQi​​ for some value of === (probably ≃+*).
A corollary of this is ∑ieifi=[L:K]\sum_ie_if_i=[L:K]∑i​ei​fi​=[L:K], and even that would be pretty cool to have.

Thanks a lot !
We were thinking of having a go at https://kconrad.math.uconn.edu/blurbs/gradnumthy/frobeniuspf.pdf, or Theorem 1 in https://kconrad.math.uconn.edu/blurbs/gradnumthy/dedekindf.pdf.

Kevin Buzzard said:

Here is something I would very much like to have in Lean: if L/KL/KL/K is a finite extension of global fields and PPP is a prime of KKK which splits as ∏iQiei\prod_iQ_i^{e_i}∏i​Qiei​​ in LLL then KP⊗KL=⨁iLQiK_P\otimes_KL=\bigoplus_iL_{Q_i}KP​⊗K​L=⨁i​LQi​​ for some value of === (probably ≃+*).

Sounds like it would be quite an interesting result to work on, although I think it's a bit too advanced for me !
So "Theorem 1 (Dedekind)" in dedekindf.pdf ? Is that "Dedekind's Theorem"?
I think so !
I think you would be better off proving a relative result.
A relative result in what sense ?

If L/KL/KL/K is a finite extension of number fields and if α∈OL\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_Lα∈OL​ such that L=K(α)L=K(\alpha)L=K(α) and p∤[OL:OK[α]]p\nmid[\mathcal{O}_L:\mathcal{O}_K[\alpha]]p∤[OL​:OK​[α]] then for all PPP of OK\mathcal{O}_KOK​ whose norm is coprime to [OL:OK[α]][\mathcal{O}_L:\mathcal{O}_K[\alpha]][OL​:OK​[α]], the factorization of the min poly for α\alphaα over KKK modulo PPP corresponds to the decomposition of POLP\mathcal{O}_LPOL​ into primes. And you should not just prove an existence theorem -- the "theorem" is a definition which writes down an explicit map between two finite types and then proves that this map is a bijection.
Working in this generality will be much easier.
If it looks intimidating just pretend K=QK=\mathbb{Q}K=Q in your head because it's the same proof which works in the general case.

In fact translating Conrad's proof over Q\mathbb{Q}Q into a general argument over KKK will be a very interesting mathematical project, and then you could formalise the general case in Lean whilst doing the translation on paper, and if you get stuck on any Lean bits then just sorry them. Don't make any definitions -- everything you need is there.
Oh right that makes sense. That would definitely be a very interesting project to work on, thanks a lot for the advice !

Port it from the top down. First try to state it. This will be much harder than you think but Damiano will be able to tell you the API. The actual construction itself will be that if k:=OK/Pk:=\mathcal{O}_K/Pk:=OK​/P then to a monic irreducible polynomial p(x)∈k[x]p(x)\in k[x]p(x)∈k[x] which is a factor mod PPP of the min poly f(x)f(x)f(x) of α\alphaα you will need to make some explicit construction of a prime ideal. It will be really cool to see how abstract and golfy the actual bijection will end up.

You can lift fff to OL/POL\mathcal{O}_L/P\mathcal{O_L}OL​/POL​ and this is canonically isomorphic to ⨁i(OL/πiei)\bigoplus_i(\mathcal{O}_L/\pi_i^{e_i})⨁i​(OL​/πiei​​). If you do careful planning there could be something really cool here.

You should really do it over all global fields and assume that L/KL/KL/K is separable, because again this will be no harder than the number field case. We have the theorem that ideals factor uniquely into prime ideals so all the ingredients are there.
I'll definitely have a got at that, thanks again !

Indeed, thanks Kevin!

I also want to emphasize one of the great strengths of formalizing. If you formalize a proof, thinking of your special case (e.g. Q\mathbb{Q}Q in this case), and Lean confirms that all the steps work for a general global field, you achieve two goals:

  • you proved a more general result;
  • normally you also understand the proof in the more general case much better!

This is a very important consequence of using a proof assistant!
